node.title: 'They're not dead': It's so cold in Florida that iguanas are falling out of trees, again
node.description: The US National Weather Service Miami-South Florida warns locals and visitors that immobilised iguanas may fall out of trees due to unusual cold temperatures across the region.
node.content:
["The US\u00a0National Weather Service for\u00a0Miami-South Florida has warned locals and visitors that immobilised iguanas might\u00a0fall out of trees due to unusually cold temperatures across the region.", "\"Iguanas are cold-blooded,\" the service explained.", "\"They slow down or become immobile when temps drop into the [4 to 9 degrees\u00a0Celsius].", "\"They may fall from trees, but they are not dead.\"", "Temperatures in South Florida reached a low of -3.8\u00a0C on Sunday, according to the National Weather Service, and high temperatures on Sunday were expected to remain above 10C.", "The\u00a0north-east of the US was walloped on Saturday by a deadly winter storm\u00a0that prompted several states to declare emergencies and forced the cancellation of more than 1,400 flights.", "Zoologist Stacey Cohen, a reptile expert at Palm Beach Zoo in Florida, explained the iguana phenomenon.", "\"Their bodies basically start to shut down where they lose their functions and, so, they are up in the trees on the branches sleeping and then, because it gets so cold, they lose that ability to hang on and then they do fall out of trees a lot,\" she said.", "Although most of the reptiles will likely survive this period of immobilisation, she\u00a0said freezing temperatures were a threat to their survival and pointed to a cold snap in 2010 that wiped out a large number of the population.", "\"Cold is a very, very life-threatening thing for them because they are from parts of Central and South America close to the equator, where it always stays very warm,\" she said.", "", "
An iguana hanging out for the temperatures to warm up in southern Florida.(AP Photo: Wilfredo Lee)
", "Green iguanas are not native to Florida, according to the Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission.", "They were accidentally introduced as stowaways in cargo ships and are considered an invasive species. They can weigh up to 7.5 kg\u00a0and measure more than\u00a01.50 metres in length.", "These iguanas are not the first animals to suffer the cold this winter.", "Hundreds of thousands of farmed fish died from thermal shock in a lagoon in north-western Greece after a heavy snowstorm crippled the country last week.", "Reuters"]
